intro: Calochortus coeruleus var. westonii, commonly known as the Western blue gentian, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Ranunculaceae and is characterized by its showy, sky-blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its leaves are basal, lance-shaped, and often covered in a fine layer of white powder. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
